perc_hh_without_internet.long_name: Percentage of households without internet access
perc_hh_without_internet.short_description: Percentage of households self-reported to not have internet access at home

perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.short_name: Households with cable, fiber optic, or DSL
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.long_name: Percentage of households with a high speed internet service (cable, fiber optic, or DSL)
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.short_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a high speed internet service (cable, fiber optic, or DSL)
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a high speed internet service. A high speed internet service is defined as a cable, fiber optic, or DSL internet connection. Based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} have a cable, fiber optic, or DSL internet connection.

perc_hh_with_broadband.short_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a broadband internet connection (any type of internet other than a dial-up)
perc_hh_with_broadband.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a broadband internet connection. Broadband internet is defined as any type of internet other than a dial-up. Based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
perc_hh_with_broadband.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} have a broadband connection.

perc_w_int_25_3_using_devices.short_description: Percent of the internet-connected population with a good internet speed (above 25/3 MB/s, able to stream video or online game for one device).
perc_w_int_25_3_using_devices.statement: {value} of the internet-connected population in {features.name} has a good internet speed.

perc_total_100_20_using_devices.short_description: Percent of the total population with a fast internet speed (above 100/20 MB/s, able to stream HD video on multiple devices or download large files quickly).

perc_w_int_100_20_using_devices.short_description: Percent of the internet-connected population with a fast internet speed (above 100/20 MB/s, able to stream HD video on multiple devices or download large files quickly).

median_household_income.short_description: Self-reported median household income in the past 12 months (in 2019 inflation adjusted-dollars.
median_household_income.statement: The median household income in {features.name} is {value} per year.

prevent_hosp_rate.long_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees. Ambulatory care refers to diagnoses that are usually treatable in outpatient settings. This data is based on Medicare claims and comes from County Health Rankings.

urgent_3sfca.long_name: Urgent care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
urgent_3sfca.short_description: Index of urgent care availability based on supply and demand of facilities
urgent_3sfca.long_description: Urgent care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
urgent_3sfca.statement: The urgent care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

urgent_cnt.long_name: Availability of urgent care by count
urgent_cnt.short_description: Count of urgent care facilities based on facility locations
urgent_cnt.long_description: Count of urgent care facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from Google Maps.
urgent_cnt.statement: There are {value} urgent care facilities in {features.name}.

urgent_near_10_median.long_name: Urgent care availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
urgent_near_10_median.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest urgent care facilities
urgent_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest urgent care facilities. Facility location data were collected from Google Maps. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
urgent_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest urgent care facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

primcare_e2sfca.long_name: Primary care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
primcare_e2sfca.short_description: Index of primary care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
primcare_e2sfca.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
primcare_e2sfca.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

ped_e2sfca.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
ped_e2sfca.short_description: Index of pediatric care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
ped_e2sfca.long_description: Pediatric care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of pediatricians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
ped_e2sfca.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

obgyn_e2sfca.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
obgyn_e2sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers
obgyn_e2sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.

mental_3sfca.long_name: Mental health services geographic availability (3-step  floating catchment areas)
mental_3sfca.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
mental_3sfca.long_description: Mental health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
mental_3sfca.statement: The mental health services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

mental_cnt.short_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations
mental_cnt.long_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations. Location data were collected from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) repository.
mental_cnt.statement: There are {value} mental health facilities in {features.name}.

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

mental_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest mental health facilities. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
mental_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest mental health facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

subs_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health services facilities. acs_postsecondary_percent.long_name: Estimated Percentage of Population With Any Postsecondary Education
acs_postsecondary_percent.short_description: Percentage of the population who reported any postsecondary education.
acs_postsecondary_percent.long_description: Percentage of the population who reported any postsecondary education, according to the U.S. Census American Community Survey 5-year estimates.
acs_postsecondary_percent.statement: {value} of those in {region_name} report any postsecondary education.

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B06009, via the API

schools_2year_with_science_program_per_1.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_science_program_per_1.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 41) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 41, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_science_program_per_1.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a science program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.long_name: 2-year physical science programs per 100k people over 14
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with physical science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with physical science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 40) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 40, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_physical_program_per_.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a physical science program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_2year_with_engineering_program_p.long_name: 2-year engineering or related programs per 100k people over 14
schools_2year_with_engineering_program_p.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with engineering or related programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_engineering_program_p.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with engineering or related programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 14 or 15) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 14 or 15, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_engineering_program_p.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a engineering or related program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_2year_with_computer_program_per_.long_name: 2-year computer science programs per 100k people over 14
schools_2year_with_computer_program_per_.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with computer science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_computer_program_per_.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with computer science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 11) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 11, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_computer_program_per_.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a computer science program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_2year_with_biomedical_program_pe.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with biomedical programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_with_biomedical_program_pe.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with biomedical programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 26) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 26, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_biomedical_program_pe.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a biomedical program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

schools_under2year_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest <2-year schools.
schools_under2year_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
schools_under2year_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a <2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

schools_under2year_per_100k.statement: There are {value} <2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

daycare_under_10_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
daycare_under_10_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
daycare_under_10_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_under_10_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
daycare_over_4_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
daycare_over_4_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_over_4_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

daycare_per_1k.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
daycare_per_1k.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
daycare_per_1k.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
daycare_per_1k.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

daycare_min_drivetime.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
daycare_min_drivetime.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
daycare_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

daycare_capacity.short_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.
daycare_capacity.long_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.

percent_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the percent of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
percent_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households
percent_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
percent_food_insecure.statement: {value} percent of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

number_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households
number_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

Cost_Per_Meal.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
Cost_Per_Meal.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
Cost_Per_Meal.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

Num_Child_Food_Insecure.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

mrfei.short_description: The number of available healthy and less healthy food retailers. A higher score indicates more available healthy options per less healthy options. A score of 0 indicates no available options (food desert).
mrfei.long_description: The number of available healthy and less healthy food retailers. A higher score indicates more available healthy options per less healthy options. A score of 0 indicates no available options (food desert).
mrfei.statement: The Retail food environment index is {value} in {features.name}.
